Events.RelatedDescription: Merged pull request "Fixing popularity transfer download count bug, surfacing additional validation info" (#9710) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
1. The Popularity Transfer Admin Panel has a bug where it shows version-specific download counts for packages, rather than the package registration's download count, which is what we want (we transfer popularity from one package registration to another). I had to refactor some code to get that data correctly. This now works:
(DEV packages: https://dev.nugettest.org/packages/Newtonsoft.Json/)
![image](https://github.com/NuGet/NuGetGallery/assets/82980589/cfb0981a-0010-420b-95e6-4a25811e3eef)


2. I also added some more validation info to the Admin Panel page, which should save us from having to go look in the SQL DB manually every time every time: 
![image](https://github.com/NuGet/NuGetGallery/assets/82980589/2650b9a4-7113-429b-8f71-1dcf02f1f2a6)

Events.RelatedDescription: Merged pull request "Refactored FrameworkCompatibilityService for use in NuGet.Jobs" (#9733) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
We want to reuse the `FrameworkCompatibilityService` in the NuGet.Jobs repo to get packages' computed frameworks in the Search index-builder jobs. To make this code easier to reuse, I made it a static class. I also updated all its existing references and tests.

Part of https://github.com/NuGet/Engineering/issues/4979

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "[NuGet.org Bug]: net8.0-windows does not show as a computed compatible framework for a net6.0-windows and net7.0-windows packages" (#9734) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
### Impact

It's more difficult to complete my work

### Describe the bug

We are developing .Net controls for different platforms. This month we tested all our controls for compatibility with .Net 8. .Net 6 packages are fully compatible and can work under .Net 8, but Nuget.org doesn't show net8.0-windows in the list of computed frameworks for all the packages which target net6.0-windows.
The same happens with other platforms like Android or iOS: https://github.com/NuGet/NuGetGallery/issues/9711

Nuget.org only shows net8.0 for all platforms if original target is net6.0 without platform specifier. But it is not possible to use for WinForms or WPF packages.

### Repro Steps

Open this link: https://www.nuget.org/packages/C1.WPF.Core/7.0.20233.662#supportedframeworks-body-tab

### Expected Behavior

net8.0-windows should present in the list of additional computed target frameworks

### Screenshots

![image](https://github.com/NuGet/NuGetGallery/assets/19591075/e4005849-0a3b-4939-bfe6-bb08848be3fd)


### Additional Context and logs

_No response_

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Solution level NuGetAuditLevel settings" (#13022) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
### NuGet Product(s) Involved

Visual Studio Package Management UI

### The Elevator Pitch

When dealing with a solution with a lot of projects it is difficult to delay dealing with the `NuGetAudit `errors. 

A solution level `NuGetAuditLevel` setting to adjust the entire solution would be appreciated. 

### Additional Context and Details

My solution uses `TreatWarningsAsErrors` and after updating VS to 17.8.0 I now have 26 failed projects in my solution due to nuget audit errors. My team has opted to work on these package updates on a separate timeline which means I need a way to proceed with my work without updating. Changing the audit level in 26 projects is annoying and I will want to change it back when I push my work so that the vulnerabilities stay visible.

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Add responsive testing section in UI guidelines doc." (#12991) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody: We can improve our UI development process by adding responsive testing in multiple resolutions.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "[Bug Bah] Incorrect installed package version and description will show in “Installed” tab when uninstalling a package which was installed with floating version" (#13021) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
### NuGet Product Used

Visual Studio Package Management UI

### Product Version

Dev\6.9.0.34

### Worked before?

Didn't work since it is a new feature.

### Impact

It bothers me. A fix would be nice

### Repro Steps & Context

#### Repro Steps:
1.Create a C# Console App (.NET Core 8.0) in VS.
2.Right-Click the project in the Solution Explorer window and select ‘Manage NuGet Packages…’.
3.Select the source “nuget.org” in the “Package source:” drop-down list and go to “Browse” tab.
4.Click a package (e.g. Newtonsoft.Json) and type a floating version (e.g. *) in the "Version" drop-down box on the right panel.
5.Click “Install” button and go to “Installed” tab.
6.Click the “X” button on the installed package when hovering on to uninstall it.

#### Expected:
No incorrect installed package version and description show in “Installed” tab.

#### Actual:
Incorrect installed package version and description will show in “Installed” tab as below screenshot.
![image](https://github.com/NuGet/Home/assets/20632625/f56d35a2-99d2-4939-99f5-5a5c821a1cb2)
#### Notes:
1.Repeo rate: 100%.
2.It doesn’t repro when the package is not installed with floating version.
3.It also reproes when the floating version is in the minor version(e.g. type “12.*” in the step4).

### Verbose Logs

_No response_

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Nuget requires Paketsource assignment on almost every package" (#13020) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
### NuGet Product(s) Affected

Visual Studio Package Management UI, Visual Studio Package Manager Console

### Current Behavior

I'm not sure when it started but my Nuget packge manager in Visual Studio now doesn't recognize packages until I manually given it their Sourcename. This is very annoying and other users i asked personally do not even have the option to change their package source tight from the installtion tool.

My window looks like this right now: 
![Screenshot_nuget](https://github.com/NuGet/Home/assets/125959666/3866f86e-c14b-42d0-bfba-791b256e0dc7)

just to clarify, because the picture is in german, the part behind the red x is my problem it says: Requires Packagesource assignment.



### Desired Behavior

This wasn't the case like 3 months ago, but since then more and more packages required that and the package source required is just the name of the package e.g. 'System.Drawing.Common' or something. So i hope there is a way to just download the packages without this requirement. 

### Additional Context

I already tried to reinstall my Visual Studio, this didn´t work.

So Probably there is some residual userdata file with saves my config of VS, but before a start scraping my whole filesystem I wanted to try it here.


Thank you in advance

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "[Connection] Deprecating legacy cipher suites at www.nuget.org" (#63) at NuGet/Announcements
Events.RelatedBody:
In order to provide a more secure and compliant environment for our customers, we are planning to deprecate legacy cipher suites and only support the following cipher suites at [www.nuget.org](http://www.nuget.org/):

TLS_ECDHE_RSA_WITH_AES_256_GCM_SHA384
TLS_ECDHE_RSA_WITH_AES_128_GCM_SHA256
TLS_ECDHE_RSA_WITH_AES_256_CBC_SHA384
TLS_ECDHE_RSA_WITH_AES_128_CBC_SHA256
TLS_ECDHE_RSA_WITH_AES_256_CBC_SHA
TLS_ECDHE_RSA_WITH_AES_128_CBC_SHA
TLS_RSA_WITH_AES_256_GCM_SHA384

Between 08/31/2022 07:00 PM UTC and 09/02/2022 07:00 PM UTC, we will take a test for this deprecation to understand the broken change for our customers. Based on our telemetry, we expect the impact to be minimal, but if you meet any connection issues at [www.nuget.org](http://www.nuget.org/) or have any questions, do reach out to us at [support@nuget.org](mailto:support@nuget.org) or by commenting on the discussion issue: https://github.com/NuGet/NuGetGallery/issues/9216. We will be closely monitoring our communication channels to assess any unexpected impact.

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "The NuGet.org repository signing certificate will be updated as soon as March 15th, 2021" (#53) at NuGet/Announcements
Events.RelatedBody:
The current NuGet.org repository signing certificate will be updated as soon as March 15th, 2021. If you validate that packages are repository signed by NuGet.org using a [NuGet client policy](https://docs.microsoft.com/nuget/consume-packages/installing-signed-packages), the [`NuGet.exe verify`](https://docs.microsoft.com/nuget/reference/cli-reference/cli-ref-verify) command, or the [`dotnet nuget verify`](https://docs.microsoft.com/dotnet/core/tools/dotnet-nuget-verify) command, you will need to take steps by March 15th, 2021 to avoid disruptions when installing packages from NuGet.org that are signed with the new certificate. 

If you are unsure if you will be impacted or want to see instructions to allow the new certificate, please see our blogpost on the matter: https://devblogs.microsoft.com/nuget/the-nuget-org-repository-signing-certificate-will-be-updated-as-soon-as-march-15th-2021/

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "The Microsoft author-signing certificate will be updated as soon as August 14th, 2023" (#70) at NuGet/Announcements
Events.RelatedBody:
The current Microsoft author-signing certificate will be updated as soon as August 14th, 2023.  If you validate that packages are author signed by Microsoft using a [NuGet client policy](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/nuget/consume-packages/installing-signed-packages) or the [`verify`](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/nuget/reference/cli-reference/cli-ref-verify) command, you will need to take steps to avoid disruptions when installing Microsoft packages signed with the new certificate.

If you are unsure if you will be impacted or want to see instructions to allow the new certificate, please see our blog post on the matter: https://devblogs.microsoft.com/nuget/microsoft-author-signing-certificate-update-2023/
